cleaned_text: Chief Executive Officer at Access to Advanced Health Institute The development of next-generation vaccines for COVID-19 has definitely been "de-warped", as outlined in this excellent article today in [The New York Times](https://www.linkedin.com/company/the-new-york-times?trk=public_post-text). Benjamin Mueller writes: "...as a third pandemic winter begins in the United States, its vaccine-making effort has lost steam. Efforts to test and produce next-generation Covid vaccines are bogged down by bureaucratic problems and funding shortfalls...creating a scenario in which Americans would have to travel abroad for the latest in American vaccine technology....Even with the pandemic still taking a heavy toll, prospects have dimmed for the two most coveted kinds of next-generation vaccines: nasal sprays that can block more infections, and universal coronavirus shots that can defend against a wider array of ever-evolving variants." Now is not the time to abandon some of the most promising vaccine technologies for both this and future inevitable pandemics.
